column1: Noblesville is a city in and the county seat of Hamilton County
column2: Indiana
column4: just north of Indianapolis along the White River. The population was 51
column5: 969 at the 2010 census making it the state's 14th largest city/town
column6: up from 19th in 2007. As of 2019 the estimated population was 64
column7: 668. The city is part of Delaware

column1: Noblesville is home to the Ruoff Music Center
column2: an outdoor music venue.

column1: Noblesville's history dates to 1818 when the government purchased the land which is now Hamilton County from the Native Americans in this area. William Conner
column2: the only settler living in the area at the time
column5: established the first trading post in central Indiana in 1802 and lived in the area's first log cabin. William Conner and Josiah Polk laid out what is now downtown Noblesville in 1823
column6: which was designated as the Hamilton County seat in 1824 and incorporated in 1851. Conner's 1823 home is now one of a village of historic buildings that make up Conner Prairie Pioneer Settlement
column7: a living history museum south of Noblesville in Fishers.

column1: Noblesville was named either for James Noble
column2: one of the first two US senators from Indiana
column6: to whom Josiah Polk was engaged.

column1: The Peru and Indianapolis Railroad was completed through town in 1851
column2: strengthening the town economically and causing the population to increase. In 1875 work began on the town's second railroad
column5: later known as the Midland.The city's first large growth period occurred during the Indiana gas boom
column6: with the discovery in 1888 of Noblesville's first natural gas well near 11th and Pleasant streets. Many Victorian homes
column7: as well as most of the downtown commercial district
column8: were built during this time of prosperity. The city has undergone another increase recently as its population grew from 28
column10: 969 in 2010. This growth echoes the increase in population of much of southern Hamilton County due to its proximity to Indianapolis.

column1: Noblesville was once noted for its flour mills
column2: the mostly widely known of which was the Noblesville Milling Company
column3: producer of Diadem and Kismet flours. In 1925
column4: the manager of the company offered to buy uniforms for the local high school athletic team in exchange for the school adopting the nickname "Millers". The nickname persists to this day.Other prominent businesses included the Union Sanitary Manufacturing Company
column5: the American Strawboard Company and Firestone Industrial Products.

column1: Among the notable disasters that have struck the town are the Great Flood of 1913
column2: an interurban wreck on the courthouse square in 1919
column3: and the Goeke fire of 1967. The fire
column4: which began at the Paul Goeke auto dealership just off the square
column5: destroyed two buildings and killed a firefighter'.

column1: The old Hamilton County Sheriff's Residence and Jail on the southwest corner of the courthouse square in downtown Noblesville is now the home of the Hamilton County Museum of History. As a working jail
column2: it once housed Charles Manson as a teenager and D. C. Stephenson
column3: former Grand Dragon of the Indiana Ku Klux Klan. The Stephenson trial
column4: which took place in the adjoining Hamilton County courthouse in 1925
column5: broke the power of the Klan in Indiana and drew national attention to Noblesville. Stephenson was convicted of second-degree murder in the death of Madge Oberholtzer.

column2: Noblesville was one of several Indiana towns where the Ku Klux Klan was active
column3: but the Klan's influence quickly faded after Stephenson's conviction. In 1973 Klansmen staging a march in Noblesville were met by counter-demonstrators carrying anti-Klan placards.In 1995
column4: a local contractor stumbled across a trunk containing Klan paraphernalia and membership records from the 1920s. The debate over how to handle the sensitive issue again put Noblesville in the national spotlight. The Hamilton County Historical Society
column6: opted to keep the public from seeing the former members' names.

column1: Noblesville also attracted national media attention in 1965 when Noblesville Daily Ledger editor James T. Neal was charged with contempt by Hamilton County Circuit Court judge Ed New. Neal's fight for the First Amendment went before the Indiana Supreme Court. In May 2018
column2: it drew national attention again as the Noblesville West Middle School was the site of a school shooting with a teacher and student injured.

column1: The centerpiece of downtown Noblesville is the Courthouse Square
column2: the location of the Hamilton County Courthouse (completed in 1879) and the Hamilton County Sheriff's Residence and Jail (constructed in 1876). Both buildings are fabulous examples of the Second Empire style featuring mansard roofs. Sites and buildings in Noblesville that are listed on the National Register of Historic Places include the Hamilton County Courthouse Square
column10: Nickel Plate Road Steam Locomotive No. 587

column1: Noblesville is located in central Hamilton County at 40°3′0″N 86°1′17″W (40.049935
column2: −86.021462). It is bordered to the north by Cicero
column3: to the south by Fishers and Carmel
column4: and to the west by Westfield. A narrow portion of Noblesville extends east to the Madison County line
column5: where it is bordered by the town of Ingalls.

column1: Noblesville is 23 miles (37 km) north-northeast of downtown Indianapolis. Indiana State Road 37 is the main highway through the city
column2: running east of downtown. It leads south to Interstate 69 in Fishers and thence to Indianapolis
column3: and northeast 43 miles (69 km) to Marion. Conner Street
column5: is the main east-west road through the center of Noblesville. SR 32 leads east-northeast 18 miles (29 km) to Anderson and west 6 miles (10 km) to Westfield
column6: while SR 38 leads east-southeast 14 miles (23 km) to Pendleton and northwest 13 miles (21 km) to Sheridan. Indiana State Road 19 runs north from Noblesville

column2: Noblesville has a total area of 32.785 square miles (84.91 km2)
column3: of which 31.37 square miles (81.25 km2) (or 95.68%) is land and 1.415 square miles (3.66 km2) (or 4.32%) is water.
